# Your Job

Scrape the South Shore Stars School & Learning Center website (southshorestars.org) to gather comprehensive information including:

- Detailed program descriptions and curriculum
- Admissions requirements and process
- Tuition costs and financial aid options
- Staff qualifications and teaching methodologies
- Class sizes and student-teacher ratios
- Therapy services offered (OT, speech, etc.)
- School calendar and daily schedule
- Contact information for admissions
- Any parent testimonials or success stories
- Application forms and deadlines

Focus specifically on information relevant to elementary-age students (grades 1-6) with learning disabilities. Save all findings in an organized report with direct quotes and source links.

name: brave-search
description: Web search and content extraction via Brave Search API. Use for searching documentation, facts, or any web content. Lightweight, no browser required.
---

# Brave Search

Web search and content extraction using the official Brave Search API. No browser required.

## Setup

Requires a Brave Search API account with a free subscription. A credit card is required to create the free subscription (you won't be charged).

1. Create an account at https://api-dashboard.search.brave.com/register
2. Create a "Free AI" subscription
3. Create an API key for the subscription
4. Add to your shell profile (`~/.profile` or `~/.zprofile` for zsh):
   ```bash
   export BRAVE_API_KEY="your-api-key-here"
   ```
5. Install dependencies (run once):
   ```bash
   cd {baseDir}
   npm install
   ```

## Search

```bash
{baseDir}/search.js "query"                         # Basic search (5 results)
{baseDir}/search.js "query" -n 10                   # More results (max 20)
{baseDir}/search.js "query" --content               # Include page content as markdown
{baseDir}/search.js "query" --freshness pw          # Results from last week
{baseDir}/search.js "query" --freshness 2024-01-01to2024-06-30  # Date range
{baseDir}/search.js "query" --country DE            # Results from Germany
{baseDir}/search.js "query" -n 3 --content          # Combined options
```

### Options

- `-n <num>` - Number of results (default: 5, max: 20)
- `--content` - Fetch and include page content as markdown
- `--country <code>` - Two-letter country code (default: US)
- `--freshness <period>` - Filter by time:
  - `pd` - Past day (24 hours)
  - `pw` - Past week
  - `pm` - Past month
  - `py` - Past year
  - `YYYY-MM-DDtoYYYY-MM-DD` - Custom date range

## Extract Page Content

```bash
{baseDir}/content.js https://example.com/article
```

Fetches a URL and extracts readable content as markdown.

## Output Format

```
--- Result 1 ---
Title: Page Title
Link: https://example.com/page
Age: 2 days ago
Snippet: Description from search results
Content: (if --content flag used)
  Markdown content extracted from the page...

--- Result 2 ---
...
```

## When to Use

- Searching for documentation or API references
- Looking up facts or current information
- Fetching content from specific URLs
- Any task requiring web search without interactive browsing

# Stars School & Learning Center, Weymouth, MA

## A School Where Confidence Grows and Community Matters.

**When a bright child struggles in school, it is often a sign they need a different approach.**

Many students with dyslexia and other language-based learning differences are capable, curious, and smart; they simply learn differently. When teaching does not match how their brain works, school can begin to feel frustrating, and confidence often takes a hit.

Stars School & Learning Center is a private nonprofit day school in Weymouth, Massachusetts, serving students in **grades 1-8** with dyslexia and other language-based learning differences.

We offer a structured, supportive environment with small class sizes, evidence-based instruction, and individualized support; all rooted in scientific research and best practices.

### What your child can expect:

* A **personalized learning plan** based on diagnostic information
* Expert instruction from **Orton-Gillingham** certified teachers, using state-of-the-art materials and proven methods to address specific learning differences
* **Individual academic support** to build skills and confidence
* A school community that values **belonging, friendships, and a love of learning**

Under the leadership of Dr. Renée Heywood, Stars School & Learning Center continues a strong legacy of supporting children with language-based learning differences. Our belief is simple: when students receive the right instruction, they can thrive both academically and emotionally.

In addition to our day school, students may also participate in enrichment, summer, and after-school programs.

### Is Stars School & Learning Center the right fit?

**This school may be a good fit if your child:**

Is bright but struggles with reading, writing, or language

Has dyslexia or a language-based learning difference

Has ADHD as a co-occurring challenge

Needs structured, multi-sensory instruction

Is not thriving in a traditional classroom

**This may not be the right fit if:**

Your child does not have language-based learning needs

You are looking for a general enrichment program

Your child is best served in a large, traditional classroom

### Upcoming Events

### In-Person

March 5 @ 5:30 pm - 7:00 pm

### Virtual

March 9 @ 11:30 am - 12:00 pm

March 9 @ 6:00 pm - 6:30 pm

![STARS-2-richard](https://southshorestars.org/wp-content/uploads/bb-plugin/cache/STARS-2-richard-300x300-circle-674efcd78e5057c82d9c6dec0e82057c-niqy4pfsgad5.webp "STARS-2-richard")

#### Meet our School Director

### Richard Bransfield

Richard Bransfield is a highly respected educator with more than 40 years of service in K–12 public education. He began his career as an elementary and middle school teacher and also coached three varsity high school teams. Rich later moved into school leadership, serving first as an assistant principal for grades 5–8 and then as principal of a K–8 school. 
In Weymouth Public Schools, he led both the Talbot School and the Wessagusset School before completing his career as the district’s Executive Director of Elementary Education.

Rich is widely recognized for his expertise in literacy. Throughout his career, he worked to strengthen principals’ and district leaders’ understanding of the Science of Reading and championed the use of research-based, developmentally appropriate instruction. His commitment to ensuring that every child learns to read with confidence has shaped the work of educators across the district and continues to influence his leadership today.

Learn more or connect directly: [rbransfield@southshorestars.org](mailto:rbransfield@southshorestars.org) | [781-331-8505 x461](tel:+17813318505,,461)

## How Admissions Works

We believe the admissions process begins with a conversation. Families interested in the Stars School & Learning Center are encouraged to start by submitting an inquiry to learn more about our program and determine whether it may be the right fit for their child.

After an initial inquiry, our admissions team will schedule a call with your family to discuss your child’s learning profile, answer questions, and share next steps. If appropriate, families are then invited to complete an application and are provided with any required forms as part of that process.

### School Information Packet

Families are encouraged to review our School Information Packet, which provides a deeper overview of our program, educational approach, and admissions process. This resource is designed to help families learn more about the Stars School & Learning Center prior to or during the inquiry stage.

### Ready to Get Started?

Choosing the right school can feel overwhelming. Our admissions team is here to guide you, answer questions, and help you determine whether Stars School & Learning Center is the right fit for your child.

 For Immediate Release: South Shore Stars is proud to announce the September 2025 opening of the Stars School & Learning Center in Weymouth—an innovative, nonprofit day school designed for students…
 

## Building the Gift of Literacy

### An invitation to make a meaningful difference.

Every child deserves to feel capable, confident, and understood in school. At the Stars School, we meet students where they are and teach them in the way they learn best. When instruction aligns with how a child processes language, everything begins to shift. With specialized teaching, small classrooms, and deeply committed educators, students move from frustration to confidence and from self-doubt to success.

Through Building the Gift of Literacy, we are strengthening and growing a school intentionally designed to support bright students who simply need a different approach.

We invite our community to be part of this journey.

Whether you are a parent, neighbor, business leader, educator, or friend of Stars, your support helps create a place where literacy unlocks confidence and confidence opens doors for a lifetime.

Join us. Make a gift. Share our story. Be part of building a school where every child can read, learn, and thrive.

Together, we can give the gift that changes everything.

Title: Stars School & Learning Center – South Shore Stars
Link: https://southshorestars.org/stars-school-learning-center/
Snippet: Review our mission, admission process, and how we can support your child’s journey.
Content:
## A School Where Confidence Grows and Community Matters.

**When a bright child struggles in school, it is often a sign they need a different approach.**

Many students with dyslexia and other language-based learning differences are capable, curious, and smart; they simply learn differently. When teaching does not match how their brain works, school can begin to feel frustrating, and confidence often takes a hit.

Stars School & Learning Center is a private nonprofit day school in Weymouth, Massachusetts, serving students in **grades 1-8** with dyslexia and other language-based learning differences.

We offer a structured, supportive environment with small class sizes, evidence-based instruction, and individualized support; all rooted in scientific research and best practices.

### What your child can expect:

* A **personalized learning plan** based on diagnostic information
* Expert instruction from **Orton-Gillingham** certified teachers, using state-of-the-art materials and proven methods to address specific learning differences
* **Individual academic support** to build skills and confidence
* A school community that values **belonging, friendships, and a love of learning**

Under the leadership of Dr. Renée Heywood, Stars School & Learning Center continues a strong legacy of supporting children with language-based learning differences. Our belief is simple: when students receive the right instruction, they can thrive both academically and emotionally.

In addition to our day school, students may also participate in enrichment, summer, and after-school programs.

### Is Stars School & Learning Center the right fit?

**This school may be a good fit if your child:**

Is bright but struggles with reading, writing, or language

Has dyslexia or a language-based learning difference

Has ADHD as a co-occurring challenge

Needs structured, multi-sensory instruction

Is not thriving in a traditional classroom

**This may not be the right fit if:**

Your child does not have language-based learning needs

You are looking for a general enrichment program

Your child is best served in a large, traditional classroom

### Upcoming Events

### In-Person

March 5 @ 5:30 pm - 7:00 pm

### Virtual

March 9 @ 11:30 am - 12:00 pm

March 9 @ 6:00 pm - 6:30 pm

![STARS-2-richard](https://southshorestars.org/wp-content/uploads/bb-plugin/cache/STARS-2-richard-300x300-circle-674efcd78e5057c82d9c6dec0e82057c-niqy4pfsgad5.webp "STARS-2-richard")

#### Meet our School Director

### Richard Bransfield

Richard Bransfield is a highly respected educator with more than 40 years of service in K–12 public education. He began his career as an elementary and middle school teacher and also coached three varsity high school teams. Rich later moved into school leadership, serving first as an assistant principal for grades 5–8 and then as principal of a K–8 school. 
In Weymouth Public Schools, he led both the Talbot School and the Wessagusset School before completing his career as the district’s Executive Director of Elementary Education.

Rich is widely recognized for his expertise in literacy. Throughout his career, he worked to strengthen principals’ and district leaders’ understanding of the Science of Reading and championed the use of research-based, developmentally appropriate instruction. His commitment to ensuring that every child learns to read with confidence has shaped the work of educators across the district and continues to influence his leadership today.

Learn more or connect directly: [rbransfield@southshorestars.org](mailto:rbransfield@southshorestars.org) | [781-331-8505 x461](tel:+17813318505,,461)

## How Admissions Works

We believe the admissions process begins with a conversation. Families interested in the Stars School & Learning Center are encouraged to start by submitting an inquiry to learn more about our program and determine whether it may be the right fit for their child.

After an initial inquiry, our admissions team will schedule a call with your family to discuss your child’s learning profile, answer questions, and share next steps. If appropriate, families are then invited to complete an application and are provided with any required forms as part of that process.

### School Information Packet

Families are encouraged to review our School Information Packet, which provides a deeper overview of our program, educational approach, and admissions process. This resource is designed to help families learn more about the Stars School & Learning Center prior to or during the inquiry stage.

### Ready to Get Started?

Choosing the right school can feel overwhelming. Our admissions team is here to guide you, answer questions, and help you determine whether Stars School & Learning Center is the right fit for your child.

## News, Press, & Updates

Title: Randolph Middle School Program - South Shore Stars
Link: https://southshorestars.org/programs/middle-high-school-programs/
Age: June 2, 2021
Snippet: Stars high school and middle school 21st Century Community Learning Centers provide academic, emotional and social supports during and after the traditional school day.
Content:
South Shore Stars operates **a long-standing and proven elementary out-of-school time program** in partnership with [Randolph Public Schools (RPS)](https://www.randolph.k12.ma.us/). This program is funded by the Massachusetts Department of Elementary and Secondary Education ([DESE](https://www.doe.mass.edu/)) 21st Century Community Learning Center Grant, along with private philanthropic support. To ensure equitable access, programming is offered at no cost to eligible elementary students referred by Randolph Public School educators and staff.

Stars’ 21st Century Community Learning Center provides academic, social, and emotional supports during and after the school day through engaging, project-based learning experiences. Programming is designed to strengthen academic skills while intentionally building social-emotional learning and executive functioning, helping students grow with confidence and consistency beyond the classroom.

## Building Skills for School and Life

At Stars, children learn more than academics. Our 21st Century Community Learning Center program helps elementary students build the skills they need to succeed in school, form positive relationships, and feel confident in themselves.

Through hands-on activities and supportive routines, students strengthen skills such as:

* **Managing emotions and behavior** 
 Learning how to stay focused, handle frustration, and follow daily routines.
 
* **Understanding themselves** 
 Recognizing strengths, building confidence, and developing a positive sense of self.
 
* **Getting along with others** 
 Practicing empathy, cooperation, and respect while working with peers.
 
* **Building healthy relationships** 
 Learning how to communicate, collaborate, and resolve conflicts.
 
* **Making good choices** 
 Developing age-appropriate decision-making skills and taking responsibility for actions.
 

These skills are woven into everyday activities so children feel supported, capable, and ready to learn both in and out of the classroom.

## Our programs emphasize:

A focus on developing strong, caring, supportive adult/youth relationships

Healthy social and emotional development

Promoting student participation in planning, action, and reflection

Involving students in determining program structure, goals, and activities

Creating connection between students’ school day and out-of-school time

Professional collaboration with South Shore Stars Educational Staff and RPS Staff

Using a culturally responsive approach that integrates a differentiated, equitable and inclusionary lens for all students, families, and stakeholders that we interact with

![Stars Randolph Middle School Program](https://southshorestars.org/wp-content/uploads/2026/02/Randolph-Middle-School.jpg "Randolph Middle School")

South Shore Stars’ older youth programming is built around connection, curiosity, and hands-on learning. Our activities are designed for all types of learners and blend academic enrichment with social-emotional development through engaging projects and shared experiences.

Students participate in project-based and service-learning opportunities that encourage teamwork, problem-solving, and leadership. By learning together and giving back, young people build practical skills, meaningful relationships, and a strong sense of purpose that supports success now and into the future.

![](https://southshorestars.org/wp-content/uploads/2026/02/Randolph-Middle-School-1-254x300.jpg)

“Since its inception, Stars has become an important component in supporting our students’ needs.  This program is an essential link in connecting academic achievement and afterschool activity.”

## Upcoming Dates

February 16

April 20

May 25

### Randolph Community Middle School Stars

For 6th and 7th graders 

Three 11-week cycles operate 4 days per week (Monday – Thursday) from school dismissal until 5:15 p.m.

* 2:30 – 3:15 p.m. Social Time/Snack
* 3:15 – 4:15 p.m. Academic Support with RCMS Math Teachers
* 4:15 – 5:30 p.m. Enrichment Clubs (Options may include: Robotics, Digital Media Arts, Drama, Dance)

### Randolph Summer Stars

For youth entering 6th  - 9th graders, a 4-week session including hands-on math, science and social/emotional learning and outdoor recreation. 

This short-term program is designed to support students during a key transition period by reinforcing confidence, collaboration, and problem-solving in a structured, engaging environment.

### Excellence in Education, Enrichment and Family Support

South Shore Stars provides early education, youth development, and family support programs that help children from diverse backgrounds thrive. Expanding this mission, The Stars School & Learning Center offers specialized instruction for students with dyslexia and language-based learning differences—fostering academic growth, confidence, and a love of learning.

#### Let's Connect

content.text: --- Result 1 --- Title: Stars School & Learning Center – South Shore Stars Link: https://southshorestars.org/stars-school-learning-center/ Snippet: Located in Weymouth, MA, our school will serve children in grades 1-6 with language-based learning differences, including dyslexia. Content: ## A School Where Confidence Grows and Community Matters. **When a bright child struggles in school, it is often a sign they need a different approach.** Many students with dyslexia and other language-based learning differences are capable, curious, and smart; they simply learn differently. When teaching does not match how their brain works, school can begin to feel frustrating, and confidence often takes a hit. Stars School & Learning Center is a private nonprofit day school in Weymouth, Massachusetts, serving students in **grades 1-8** with dyslexia and other language-based learning differences. We offer a structured, supportive environment with small class sizes, evidence-based instruction, and individualized support; all rooted in scientific research and best practices. ### What your child can expect: * A **personalized learning plan** based on diagnostic information * Expert instruction from **Orton-Gillingham** certified teachers, using state-of-the-art materials and proven methods to address specific learning differences * **Individual academic support** to build skills and confidence * A school community that values **belonging, friendships, and a love of learning** Under the leadership of Dr. Renée Heywood, Stars School & Learning Center continues a strong legacy of supporting children with language-based learning differences. Our belief is simple: when students receive the right instruction, they can thrive both academically and emotionally. In addition to our day school, students may also participate in enrichment, summer, and after-school programs. ### Is Stars School & Learning Center the right fit? **This school may be a good fit if your child:** Is bright but struggles with reading, writing, or language Has dyslexia or a language-based learning difference Has ADHD as a co-occurring challenge Needs structured, multi-sensory instruction Is not thriving in a traditional classroom **This may not be the right fit if:** Your child does not have language-based learning needs You are looking for a general enrichment program Your child is best served in a large, traditional classroom ### Upcoming Events ### In-Person March 5 @ 5:30 pm - 7:00 pm ### Virtual March 9 @ 11:30 am - 12:00 pm March 9 @ 6:00 pm - 6:30 pm ![STARS-2-richard](https://southshorestars.org/wp-content/uploads/bb-plugin/cache/STARS-2-richard-300x300-circle-674efcd78e5057c82d9c6dec0e82057c-niqy4pfsgad5.webp "STARS-2-richard") #### Meet our School Director ### Richard Bransfield Richard Bransfield is a highly respected educator with more than 40 years of service in K–12 public education. He began his career as an elementary and middle school teacher and also coached three varsity high school teams. Rich later moved into school leadership, serving first as an assistant principal for grades 5–8 and then as principal of a K–8 school. In Weymouth Public Schools, he led both the Talbot School and the Wessagusset School before completing his career as the district’s Executive Director of Elementary Education. Rich is widely recognized for his expertise in literacy. Throughout his career, he worked to strengthen principals’ and district leaders’ understanding of the Science of Reading and championed the use of research-based, developmentally appropriate instruction. His commitment to ensuring that every child learns to read with confidence has shaped the work of educators across the district and continues to influence his leadership today. Learn more or connect directly: [rbransfield@southshorestars.org](mailto:rbransfield@southshorestars.org) | [781-331-8505 x461](tel:+17813318505,,461) ## How Admissions Works We believe the admissions process begins with a conversation. Families interested in the Stars School & Learning Center are encouraged to start by submitting an inquiry to learn more about our program and determine whether it may be the right fit for their child. After an initial inquiry, our admissions team will schedule a call with your family to discuss your child’s learning profile, answer questions, and share next steps. If appropriate, families are then invited to complete an application and are provided with any required forms as part of that process. ### School Information Packet Families are encouraged to review our School Information Packet, which provides a deeper overview of our program, educational approach, and admissions process. This resource is designed to help families learn more about the Stars School & Learning Center prior to or during the inquiry stage. ### Ready to Get Started? Choosing the right school can feel overwhelming. Our admissions team is here to guide you, answer questions, and help you determine whether Stars School & Learning Center is the right fit for your child. ## News, Press, & Updates * ## [DESE Approval for Grades K–8 at Stars School & Learning Center](https://southshorestars.org/dese-approval-for-grades-k-8-at-stars-school-learning-center/ "DESE Approv --- Result 2 --- Title: Weymouth’s Stars School & Learning Center aims to help dyslexic kids Link: https://www.bostonglobe.com/2025/01/31/lifestyle/dyslexic-kids-are-often-underserved-left-behind-new-south-shore-school-could-help/ Age: January 31, 2025 Snippet: Stars tuition is $67,000. Curtis says that Stars has received provisional approval as a state-approved 766 school. These schools offer specialized private instruction and can work with school districts to access a portion of tuition through ... Content: Weymouth’s [Stars School & Learning Center](https://southshorestars.org/stars-school-learning-center/) plans to launch in September. It’s dedicated to elementary students with language-based learning needs, such as dyslexia. Stars is an offshoot of the South Shore Stars educational nonprofit, which started as a daycare in the early ‘70s and evolved to include youth programming for all ages. Get Starting Point A guide through the most important stories of the morning, delivered Monday through Friday. Enter Email Former Weymouth Schools Superintendent, principal, and classroom teacher Jennifer Curtis leads the school with a staff certified in Orton-Gillingham, including a speech and language pathologist and multiple reading specialists. Orton-Gillingham is a phonics-intensive, research-based method often used with dyslexic students. Aside from specialized instruction, Curtis says Stars resembles a mainstream elementary school, with specials like music and gym. Stars tuition is $67,000. Curtis says that Stars has received provisional approval as a state-approved 766 school. These schools offer specialized private instruction and can work with school districts to access a portion of tuition through the circuit-breaker program, a state-funded reimbursement process. This means that, in some cases, qualifying students could receive out-of-district placements from their home district with a portion of costs covered. “\[The tuition\] makes me cringe a little every time I say it. It’s a lot of money. But, if you look at all the 766 schools out there, we’re surprisingly a lot less,” Curtis says. (Day student tuition at Landmark, a well-regarded 766 North Shore school focusing on dyslexia for kids in 2nd through 12th grades, is $75,500.) I talked to Curtis about the new school’s approach and about what students with dyslexia — which affects about 20 percent of the population — really need to succeed. ![Sign up for Parenting Unfiltered.](https://bostonglobe-prod.cdn.arcpublishing.com/resizer/v2/Z2IMEE234NDYJG35TCB376FG4M.jpg?auth=e8b5a1fc8a656a2a4bf16c98c0fb26b0ae9c259c5a85a7bfb652ea26c7cc3e66&width=1440) Sign up for Parenting Unfiltered.Globe staff **What’s a 766 school? Does that mean Stars is a therapeutic school?** It doesn’t have to do with anything as far as being more therapeutic — or more, or less, of something. It’s about complying with regulations that the Department of Elementary and Secondary Education put forward to meet certain benchmarks. They audit; we work collaboratively with them. This then allows us to have school districts access funds, called circuit-breaker funding, to send students \[from their\] district into our program. Does it cover all of the tuition for the school district? No, but it does give some relief if a school district has to send someone to a different placement. From a parent lens, this is called out-of-district placement. **Does the funding go to parents or to schools?** It depends. If a family is going through the IEP process and their team decides that the district does not have the services within its own programming, and the team decides it’s a better placement for a child, they work with the 766 school to develop a contract, and they send children directly. Sometimes, unfortunately, families have to hire advocates or attorneys, and it becomes a bit more litigious. We need a minimum of 12 kids to be enrolled to open our doors. We’ve had a lot of interest from families, and we’re also working with school districts that may have students to place; we’re looking at assessment packages and different student profiles to see if they’re a good fit for the program itself. **What type of documentation or testing is recommended? I know that neuropsych testing independently can be prohibitively expensive.** Some families might have a full battery of assessments, but some families do not. Some families are coming to us with the data from the dyslexia screeners from their school departments, or they’re coming with curriculum-based assessments that their school department is doing. We’re looking at that information and then taking anecdotal data to see if we’re a good fit for their child. Is a neuropsychological test good practice? Yes. But do you have to have that? No. Our team is skilled, so a lot of them can do advanced testing if needed. **Who’s the student population?** The program has been developed for kids with dyslexia or language-based learning needs. We’re making sure that our instruction is focused on being systematic, multi-sensory, and sequential, with certified Orton-Gillingham instructors. Our staff will have the training to personalize instruction based upon the learner’s needs. The ratio will be extremely low; at times, one staff member to three students. We’re scheduled to have a full-time speech and language pathologist on staff, and we really feel as though that makes a difference: It’s not just a pull-out of 30 minutes five times a week. Content: (HTTP 403) --- Result 6 --- Title: Stars School & Learning Center Sets Opening for September 2025 Link: https://southshoretimes.com/business-and-finance/stars-school-learning-center-sets-opening-for-september-2025 Age: June 4, 2025 Snippet: Enrollment is open year-round, and Stars is able to accommodate mid-year transfer students. Content: Located at 163 Libbey Parkway in Weymouth, Stars School & Learning Center will be the first school of its kind on Boston’s South Shore.SOUTH SHORE STARS Published on :  04 Jun 2025, 5:08 pm Stars School & Learning Center, a new specialized nonprofit day school serving cognitively skilled students in Grades 1–5 with dyslexia and related language-based learning differences, has officially announced its inaugural opening date: September 4, 2025. Developed and led by South Shore Stars CEO Jennifer Curtis-Whipple, Ed.D., a former Superintendent of Weymouth Public Schools, the school is a natural extension of Stars’ five-decade commitment to early education, academic enrichment, and family support. Located at 163 Libbey Parkway in Weymouth, Stars School & Learning Center will be the first school of its kind on Boston’s South Shore, offering an innovative, evidence-based, multisensory curriculum grounded in the Science of Reading within a highly supportive learning environment. Enrollment is open year-round, and Stars is able to accommodate mid-year transfer students. As a nonprofit, Chapter 766-approved day school, Stars accepts both private-pay students and those placed by public school districts. Recently approved tuition rates by the Massachusetts Operational Services Division will allow public districts to access state and municipal funding for appropriate student placements. The idea for the school was ignited three years ago when State Senator Patrick O’Connor introduced Dr. Curtis-Whipple to a group of parents seeking a solution for the lack of resources on the South Shore. In February 2023, Stars committed to launching a new school to fill that void. With necessary approvals now in place, the board recently voted to allocate all necessary resources to guarantee opening for the 2025-2026 school year. “This program is a major need on the South Shore, and similar programs throughout the eastern part of the state are full. Dyslexic students are all too frequently faced with instruction that is poorly executed and leaves the child unable to read at a useful level,” says Nancy Duggan, founder of Decoding Dyslexia of MA and a Stars board member. “The entire board recognizes the pain that parents of dyslexic students experience when their children are unhappy and, often, depressed by the gap they can see between their abilities and their classmates.” Stars has begun hiring Orton-Gillingham trained and certified teachers, Speech and Language Pathologists, and additional elementary school staff and expects to be fully staffed by July 31st. The school recently completed a $1.4 million remodeling project to create classrooms and learning spaces tailored to the needs of students with dyslexia, language-based learning needs, ADHD, and additional features to support teaching and learning for this population of children. The upgraded space features a state-of-the-art gross motor and sensory space that allows children to engage with self-regulation tools and explore a multitude of resources and equipment. A scholarship fund is being established, and leadership is now refocusing its fundraising efforts toward ensuring future financial flexibility and a sustainable future for the school and the organization. “The community needs this program, and we have worked hard to get to a point where we are able to begin providing these services. All children deserve high-quality education, and we are ready to offer this specialized instruction for children with dyslexia,” said Dr. Curtis-Whipple. “We are grateful to Quincy Mutual, South Shore Bank, Blue Cross Blue Shield of Massachusetts, Senator Patrick O’Connor, and countless others who have helped us realize this important step forward for education on the South Shore.” --- Result 7 --- Title: How can Massachusetts help public school students with dyslexia? | GBH Link: https://www.wgbh.org/news/local/2024-01-17/how-can-massachusetts-help-public-school-students-with-dyslexia Age: January 17, 2024 Snippet: Curtis said South Shore Stars is ... 766 approval, which would allow public school districts to use funds that are allocated towards special education needs to send children to South Shore Stars.... Content: Massachusetts is failing to provide sufficient instruction to students with dyslexia. That’s according to recent [reporting](https://www.bostonglobe.com/2024/01/11/metro/dyslexia-resources-ma-schools/) by the Boston Globe, which estimates there could be up to 180,000 dyslexic students enrolled in state public schools. While there are federal [standards](https://sites.ed.gov/idea/) for screening children for dyslexia required by the Individuals with Disabilities Education Act, the issue lies in connecting children with the tailored instruction they need to learn how to read. Currently, Massachusetts does not mandate specific teaching methods for dyslexia. “You need trained professionals to implement this type of teaching, and that's very expensive,” Jennifer Curtis, the former superintendent of Weymouth Public Schools, told _Boston Public Radio_ on Wednesday. Beyond cost, Curtis said there aren't enough teachers trained in effective methodologies for teaching dyslexic students to read. Dyslexia is a language-based learning disability caused by a neurological difference in how someone interprets written language into sound. “To say this squiggle on the page makes this sound in the English language, that's a learned behavior,” said Nancy Duggan, executive director of Decoding Dyslexia Massachusetts. “It's learned like swimming or basketball or playing the cello.” People with dyslexia have a harder time making those connections. The key is early intervention. “The younger we work with the students, the more likely we are able to help remedy and give them the toolbox and the skills they need to be successful readers as adults,” said Curtis. Curtis and Duggan would like to see the Orton-Gillingham method used consistently in the Commonwealth’s public schools. It’s a systematic teaching method that uses phonics and explicit meaning and is approved by the International Dyslexia Association. Some private schools are offering reading education tailored for dyslexic students to fill the gaps in the public school system. Curtis is the CEO of South Shore Stars school in Weymouth, which is focused on teaching students of a variety of learning differences. Yet the cost of these schools, which can be tens of thousands of dollars a year, could be prohibitive to the state’s neediest students. Curtis said South Shore Stars is working with the Department of Elementary and Secondary Education to receive Chapter 766 approval, which would allow public school districts to use funds that are allocated towards special education needs to send children to South Shore Stars. After receiving instruction tailored to their learning differences, the student would then return to their school districts. “They need to go out and be in their own neighborhoods,” Curtis said. At the state level, Duggan said it’s time to reframe standardized reading curriculum. The lack of curriculum standards should be seen “not as a problem of local control and state control, but of consumer protection,” she said. “We should spend \[money\] on products that are proven reliable.” --- Result 8 --- Title: Stars School & Learning Center in Weymouth Sets Opening Date for September 2025 Link: https://finance.yahoo.com/news/stars-school-learning-center-weymouth-142000744.html Age: May 21, 2025 Snippet: As a nonprofit, Chapter 766-approved day school, Stars accepts both private-pay students and those placed by public school districts. Recently approved tuition rates by the Massachusetts Operational Services Division will allow public districts ... # DESE Approval for Grades K–8 at Stars School & Learning Center

**South Shore Stars is proud to announce that the S[tars School & Learning Center](https://southshorestars.org/stars-school-learning-center/) has received approval from the Massachusetts Department of Elementary and Secondary Education (DESE) to serve students in grades K–8 with dyslexia and language-based learning differences.**

This approval affirms the Stars School & Learning Center as a DESE-approved program offering structured, evidence-based instruction in a small, supportive environment. With an expanded grade span through middle school, the school is now positioned to support students during the critical years of literacy development before they transition to high school.

“This approval from DESE is an important milestone for South Shore Stars and, more importantly, for families seeking the right educational environment for their children,” said Dr. Renée Heywood, CEO of South Shore Stars. “At the Stars School & Learning Center, students with dyslexia and language-based learning differences are understood and supported through instruction that aligns with how they learn best. Expanding our approved grade levels allows us to provide continuity of support during the years when academic demands increase and confidence matters most.”

The Stars School & Learning Center focuses on literacy, language development, and executive functioning through research-based instructional approaches delivered by highly trained educators. The program emphasizes individualized learning plans, targeted intervention, and close collaboration with families to support each student’s academic and social-emotional growth.

**Rolling Admissions Now Open**

The Stars School & Learning Center offers rolling admissions, allowing families to apply throughout the year as space becomes available. This flexible enrollment model ensures that students can access specialized support when it is most needed, rather than waiting for traditional enrollment cycles.

Families interested in learning more about enrollment, scheduling a tour, or exploring whether the Stars School & Learning Center is the right fit for their child are encouraged to [contact South Shore Stars directly](https://southshorestars.org/enrollment/).

With more than 50 years of service to children and families across Weymouth, Quincy, and Randolph, South Shore Stars continues to expand access to high-quality, inclusive education. DESE approval for grades K–8 at the Stars School & Learning Center represents a significant step forward in addressing the growing need for specialized, language-based education on the South Shore.

# Stars School & Learning Center Receives Full Chapter 766 Approval, Expanding Access to Publicly Funded Educational Support

### Excellence in Education, Enrichment and Family Support

South Shore Stars provides early education, youth development, and family support programs that help children from diverse backgrounds thrive. Content:
## A School Where Confidence Grows and Community Matters.

**When a bright child struggles in school, it is often a sign they need a different approach.**

Many students with dyslexia and other language-based learning differences are capable, curious, and smart; they simply learn differently. When teaching does not match how their brain works, school can begin to feel frustrating, and confidence often takes a hit.

Stars School & Learning Center is a private nonprofit day school in Weymouth, Massachusetts, serving students in **grades 1-8** with dyslexia and other language-based learning differences.

We offer a structured, supportive environment with small class sizes, evidence-based instruction, and individualized support; all rooted in scientific research and best practices.

### What your child can expect:

* A **personalized learning plan** based on diagnostic information
* Expert instruction from **Orton-Gillingham** certified teachers, using state-of-the-art materials and proven methods to address specific learning differences
* **Individual academic support** to build skills and confidence
* A school community that values **belonging, friendships, and a love of learning**

Under the leadership of Dr. Renée Heywood, Stars School & Learning Center continues a strong legacy of supporting children with language-based learning differences. Our belief is simple: when students receive the right instruction, they can thrive both academically and emotionally.

In addition to our day school, students may also participate in enrichment, summer, and after-school programs.

### Is Stars School & Learning Center the right fit?

**This school may be a good fit if your child:**

Is bright but struggles with reading, writing, or language

Has dyslexia or a language-based learning difference

Has ADHD as a co-occurring challenge

Needs structured, multi-sensory instruction

Is not thriving in a traditional classroom

**This may not be the right fit if:**

Your child does not have language-based learning needs

You are looking for a general enrichment program

Your child is best served in a large, traditional classroom

### Upcoming Events

### In-Person

March 5 @ 5:30 pm - 7:00 pm

### Virtual

March 9 @ 11:30 am - 12:00 pm

![STARS-2-richard](https://southshorestars.org/wp-content/uploads/bb-plugin/cache/STARS-2-richard-300x300-circle-674efcd78e5057c82d9c6dec0e82057c-niqy4pfsgad5.webp "STARS-2-richard")

#### Meet our School Director

### Richard Bransfield

Richard Bransfield is a highly respected educator with more than 40 years of service in K–12 public education. He began his career as an elementary and middle school teacher and also coached three varsity high school teams. Rich later moved into school leadership, serving first as an assistant principal for grades 5–8 and then as principal of a K–8 school. 
In Weymouth Public Schools, he led both the Talbot School and the Wessagusset School before completing his career as the district’s Executive Director of Elementary Education.

Rich is widely recognized for his expertise in literacy. Throughout his career, he worked to strengthen principals’ and district leaders’ understanding of the Science of Reading and championed the use of research-based, developmentally appropriate instruction. His commitment to ensuring that every child learns to read with confidence has shaped the work of educators across the district and continues to influence his leadership today.

Learn more or connect directly: [rbransfield@southshorestars.org](mailto:rbransfield@southshorestars.org) | [781-331-8505 x461](tel:+17813318505,,461)

## How Admissions Works

We believe the admissions process begins with a conversation. Families interested in the Stars School & Learning Center are encouraged to start by submitting an inquiry to learn more about our program and determine whether it may be the right fit for their child.

After an initial inquiry, our admissions team will schedule a call with your family to discuss your child’s learning profile, answer questions, and share next steps. If appropriate, families are then invited to complete an application and are provided with any required forms as part of that process.

### School Information Packet

Families are encouraged to review our School Information Packet, which provides a deeper overview of our program, educational approach, and admissions process. This resource is designed to help families learn more about the Stars School & Learning Center prior to or during the inquiry stage.

### Ready to Get Started?

Choosing the right school can feel overwhelming. Our admissions team is here to guide you, answer questions, and help you determine whether Stars School & Learning Center is the right fit for your child.

## News, Press, & Updates

#### Meet our School Director

### Richard Bransfield

Richard Bransfield is a highly respected educator with more than 40 years of service in K–12 public education. He began his career as an elementary and middle school teacher and also coached three varsity high school teams. Rich later moved into school leadership, serving first as an assistant principal for grades 5–8 and then as principal of a K–8 school. 
In Weymouth Public Schools, he led both the Talbot School and the Wessagusset School before completing his career as the district’s Executive Director of Elementary Education.

Rich is widely recognized for his expertise in literacy. Throughout his career, he worked to strengthen principals’ and district leaders’ understanding of the Science of Reading and championed the use of research-based, developmentally appropriate instruction. His commitment to ensuring that every child learns to read with confidence has shaped the work of educators across the district and continues to influence his leadership today.

Learn more or connect directly: [rbransfield@southshorestars.org](mailto:rbransfield@southshorestars.org) | [781-331-8505 x461](tel:+17813318505,,461)

## How Admissions Works

We believe the admissions process begins with a conversation. Families interested in the Stars School & Learning Center are encouraged to start by submitting an inquiry to learn more about our program and determine whether it may be the right fit for their child.

After an initial inquiry, our admissions team will schedule a call with your family to discuss your child’s learning profile, answer questions, and share next steps. If appropriate, families are then invited to complete an application and are provided with any required forms as part of that process.

### School Information Packet

Families are encouraged to review our School Information Packet, which provides a deeper overview of our program, educational approach, and admissions process. This resource is designed to help families learn more about the Stars School & Learning Center prior to or during the inquiry stage.

### Ready to Get Started?

Choosing the right school can feel overwhelming. Our admissions team is here to guide you, answer questions, and help you determine whether Stars School & Learning Center is the right fit for your child.

Snippet: For more information, contact Kristin Calo at kcalo@southshorestars.org
Content:
South Shore Stars operates **a long-standing and proven elementary out-of-school time program** in partnership with [Randolph Public Schools (RPS)](https://www.randolph.k12.ma.us/). This program is funded by the Massachusetts Department of Elementary and Secondary Education ([DESE](https://www.doe.mass.edu/)) 21st Century Community Learning Center Grant, along with private philanthropic support. To ensure equitable access, programming is offered at no cost to eligible elementary students referred by Randolph Public School educators and staff.

Stars’ 21st Century Community Learning Center provides academic, social, and emotional supports during and after the school day through engaging, project-based learning experiences. Programming is designed to strengthen academic skills while intentionally building social-emotional learning and executive functioning, helping students grow with confidence and consistency beyond the classroom.

## Building Skills for School and Life

At Stars, children learn more than academics. Our 21st Century Community Learning Center program helps elementary students build the skills they need to succeed in school, form positive relationships, and feel confident in themselves.

Through hands-on activities and supportive routines, students strengthen skills such as:

* **Managing emotions and behavior** 
 Learning how to stay focused, handle frustration, and follow daily routines.
 
* **Understanding themselves** 
 Recognizing strengths, building confidence, and developing a positive sense of self.
 
* **Getting along with others** 
 Practicing empathy, cooperation, and respect while working with peers.
 
* **Building healthy relationships** 
 Learning how to communicate, collaborate, and resolve conflicts.
 
* **Making good choices** 
 Developing age-appropriate decision-making skills and taking responsibility for actions.
 

These skills are woven into everyday activities so children feel supported, capable, and ready to learn both in and out of the classroom.

## Our programs emphasize:

A focus on developing strong, caring, supportive adult/youth relationships

Healthy social and emotional development

Promoting student participation in planning, action, and reflection

Involving students in determining program structure, goals, and activities

Creating connection between students’ school day and out-of-school time

Professional collaboration with South Shore Stars Educational Staff and RPS Staff

Using a culturally responsive approach that integrates a differentiated, equitable and inclusionary lens for all students, families, and stakeholders that we interact with

![Stars Randolph Middle School Program](https://southshorestars.org/wp-content/uploads/2026/02/Randolph-Middle-School.jpg "Randolph Middle School")

South Shore Stars’ older youth programming is built around connection, curiosity, and hands-on learning. Our activities are designed for all types of learners and blend academic enrichment with social-emotional development through engaging projects and shared experiences.

Students participate in project-based and service-learning opportunities that encourage teamwork, problem-solving, and leadership. By learning together and giving back, young people build practical skills, meaningful relationships, and a strong sense of purpose that supports success now and into the future.

![](https://southshorestars.org/wp-content/uploads/2026/02/Randolph-Middle-School-1-254x300.jpg)

“Since its inception, Stars has become an important component in supporting our students’ needs.  This program is an essential link in connecting academic achievement and afterschool activity.”

## Upcoming Dates

February 16

April 20

May 25

### Randolph Community Middle School Stars

For 6th and 7th graders 

Three 11-week cycles operate 4 days per week (Monday – Thursday) from school dismissal until 5:15 p.m.

* 2:30 – 3:15 p.m. Social Time/Snack
* 3:15 – 4:15 p.m. Academic Support with RCMS Math Teachers
* 4:15 – 5:30 p.m. Enrichment Clubs (Options may include: Robotics, Digital Media Arts, Drama, Dance)

### Randolph Summer Stars

For youth entering 6th  - 9th graders, a 4-week session including hands-on math, science and social/emotional learning and outdoor recreation. 

This short-term program is designed to support students during a key transition period by reinforcing confidence, collaboration, and problem-solving in a structured, engaging environment.

### Excellence in Education, Enrichment and Family Support

South Shore Stars provides early education, youth development, and family support programs that help children from diverse backgrounds thrive. Expanding this mission, The Stars School & Learning Center offers specialized instruction for students with dyslexia and language-based learning differences—fostering academic growth, confidence, and a love of learning.

In addition to our day school, students may also participate in enrichment, summer, and after-school programs. ### Is Stars School & Learning Center the right fit? **This school may be a good fit if your child:** Is bright but struggles with reading, writing, or language Has dyslexia or a language-based learning difference Has ADHD as a co-occurring challenge Needs structured, multi-sensory instruction Is not thriving in a traditional classroom **This may not be the right fit if:** Your child does not have language-based learning needs You are looking for a general enrichment program Your child is best served in a large, traditional classroom ### Upcoming Events ### In-Person March 5 @ 5:30 pm - 7:00 pm ### Virtual March 9 @ 11:30 am - 12:00 pm March 9 @ 6:00 pm - 6:30 pm ![STARS-2-richard](https://southshorestars.org/wp-content/uploads/bb-plugin/cache/STARS-2-richard-300x300-circle-674efcd78e5057c82d9c6dec0e82057c-niqy4pfsgad5.webp "STARS-2-richard") #### Meet our School Director ### Richard Bransfield Richard Bransfield is a highly respected educator with more than 40 years of service in K–12 public education. Our admissions team is here to guide you, answer questions, and help you determine whether Stars School & Learning Center is the right fit for your child. ## News, Press, & Updates * ## [DESE Approval for Grades K–8 at Stars School & Learning Center](https://southshorestars.org/dese-approval-for-grades-k-8-at-stars-school-learning-center/ "DESE Approv --- Result 2 --- Title: Stars School to Open in Weymouth This Fall Link: https://southshoretimes.com/business-and-finance/stars-school-learning-center-sets-opening-for-september-2025 Age: June 4, 2025 Snippet: Developed and led by South Shore Stars CEO Jennifer Curtis-Whipple, Ed.D., a former Superintendent of Weymouth Public Schools, the school is a natural extension of Stars’ five-decade commitment to early education, academic enrichment, and ... Content: Located at 163 Libbey Parkway in Weymouth, Stars School & Learning Center will be the first school of its kind on Boston’s South Shore.SOUTH SHORE STARS Published on :  04 Jun 2025, 5:08 pm Stars School & Learning Center, a new specialized nonprofit day school serving cognitively skilled students in Grades 1–5 with dyslexia and related language-based learning differences, has officially announced its inaugural opening date: September 4, 2025. Developed and led by South Shore Stars CEO Jennifer Curtis-Whipple, Ed.D., a former Superintendent of Weymouth Public Schools, the school is a natural extension of Stars’ five-decade commitment to early education, academic enrichment, and family support. Located at 163 Libbey Parkway in Weymouth, Stars School & Learning Center will be the first school of its kind on Boston’s South Shore, offering an innovative, evidence-based, multisensory curriculum grounded in the Science of Reading within a highly supportive learning environment. Enrollment is open year-round, and Stars is able to accommodate mid-year transfer students. As a nonprofit, Chapter 766-approved day school, Stars accepts both private-pay students and those placed by public school districts. Recently approved tuition rates by the Massachusetts Operational Services Division will allow public districts to access state and municipal funding for appropriate student placements. The idea for the school was ignited three years ago when State Senator Patrick O’Connor introduced Dr. Curtis-Whipple to a group of parents seeking a solution for the lack of resources on the South Shore. In February 2023, Stars committed to launching a new school to fill that void. With necessary approvals now in place, the board recently voted to allocate all necessary resources to guarantee opening for the 2025-2026 school year. “This program is a major need on the South Shore, and similar programs throughout the eastern part of the state are full. Dyslexic students are all too frequently faced with instruction that is poorly executed and leaves the child unable to read at a useful level,” says Nancy Duggan, founder of Decoding Dyslexia of MA and a Stars board member. “The entire board recognizes the pain that parents of dyslexic students experience when their children are unhappy and, often, depressed by the gap they can see between their abilities and their classmates.” Stars has begun hiring Orton-Gillingham trained and certified teachers, Speech and Language Pathologists, and additional elementary school staff and expects to be fully staffed by July 31st. The school recently completed a $1.4 million remodeling project to create classrooms and learning spaces tailored to the needs of students with dyslexia, language-based learning needs, ADHD, and additional features to support teaching and learning for this population of children. The upgraded space features a state-of-the-art gross motor and sensory space that allows children to engage with self-regulation tools and explore a multitude of resources and equipment. A scholarship fund is being established, and leadership is now refocusing its fundraising efforts toward ensuring future financial flexibility and a sustainable future for the school and the organization. “The community needs this program, and we have worked hard to get to a point where we are able to begin providing these services. All children deserve high-quality education, and we are ready to offer this specialized instruction for children with dyslexia,” said Dr. Curtis-Whipple. “We are grateful to Quincy Mutual, South Shore Bank, Blue Cross Blue Shield of Massachusetts, Senator Patrick O’Connor, and countless others who have helped us realize this important step forward for education on the South Shore.” --- Result 3 --- Title: South Shore Stars to open this fall: Date, tuition cost, how to enroll Link: https://www.patriotledger.com/story/news/education/2025/06/23/special-needs-school-dyslexia-adhd-weymouth-ma-jennifer-curtis-karen-whipple/84225101007/?gnt-cfr=1&gca-cat=p&gca-uir=false&gca-epti=z113302p001850c001850v113302&gca-ft=190&gca-ds=sophi&gnt-djm=1 Age: June 24, 2025 Snippet: South Shore Stars, a nonprofit education program, will open a new school for students who have a variety of learning differences this fall. Content: June 23, 2025Updated June 24, 2025, 3:29 p.m. ET [South Shore Stars](https://southshorestars.org/), a nonprofit education program, will open [a new school for students](https://www.patriotledger.com/story/news/2023/05/22/weymouth-ma-south-shore-stars-dyslexia-new-school/70223228007/) who have a variety of learning differences this fall. The Stars School & Learning Center will serve as a private, nonprofit day school for children in first through fifth grades with dyslexia and other language-based learning differences. The school will officially open Sept. 4, 2025. --- Result 4 --- Title: Weymouth school superintendent looks back on her career Link: https://www.wickedlocal.com/story/weymouth-news/2021/02/15/students-and-families-delight-weymouth-school-superintendent/6746520002/ Age: February 17, 2021 Snippet: WEYMOUTH — School Superintendent Jennifer Curtis-Whipple said she looks forward to using her professional skills as executive director for South Shore Stars, beginning March 1. Content: Feb. 15, 2021Updated Feb. 17, 2021, 10:05 a.m. ET ![Weymouth Mayor Robert Hedlund and Weymouth Superintendent of Schools Jennifer Curtis-Whipple look at items found in a time capsule that was buried in 1963 when the former Weymouth North High School - later renamed the Maria Weston Chapman Middle School - was opened that is now being demolished for a new middle school during a groundbreaking ceremony on Thursday, July 2, 2020.](https://www.wickedlocal.com/gcdn/-mm-/e2395a032e472135d86643be306130845bb8375a/c=0-146-1643-1070/local/-/media/2020/11/04/WickedLocal/ghows-WL-200709067-58f4cf54.jpg?width=660&height=372&fit=crop&format=pjpg&auto=webp) WEYMOUTH — School Superintendent Jennifer Curtis-Whipple said she looks forward to using her professional skills as executive director for South Shore Stars, beginning March 1. "I love the mission of the organization," Curtis-Whipple said. "They do phenomenal work for families and children. It ties into my value system, who I am, my professional career, and what I want to do." The nonprofit organization provides early education and youth development programs around the region. Curtis-Whipple said she has enjoyed working with "so many students and families" during her 25-year education career in Weymouth. “I specifically enjoyed working with students that have difficulty learning and being able to support them, see them flourish and grow with the right teaching strategies,” she said. Curtis-Whipple, a 1991 Weymouth High School graduate, began her education career as a kindergarten teacher at Nash Primary School in 1995. “I had multiple teacher jobs in the area of general education and literacy,” she said. “I then moved into the administration as a principal at Academy Avenue School.” Curtis-Whipple worked as a teacher for 15 years before she was promoted to principal in 2010 by then-Superintendent Mary Jo Livingstone, 54, a 1975 Weymouth South High School graduate who died unexpectedly of natural causes in April 2011.  “We have a lot of staff members that grew up here, and still live here, and chose to work here,” she said. "I think it is nice for the community and great for the kids to see.” Curtis Whipple was appointed assistant superintendent in August 2014 by former Superintendent Kenneth Salim. Her duties included coordinating curriculum instruction, special education, English as a second language or ESL, and early childhood education. The School Committee appointed Curtis-Whipple to serve as superintendent in April 2016, after Salim accepted a superintendent position with the Cambridge Public Schools. She said the school district is unique because of the dedicated work done by all employees. “I think our teachers, staff, food service workers, custodians, and administrators go above and beyond for the kids,” Curtis-Whipple said. “I think we work hard to provide as many opportunities as possible so kids and families can flourish.” She said the dedication of school employees is evident at the Johnson Early Childhood. “When you go to the Johnson preschool, it is amazing to see the range of students that are so successful in the education setting,” Curtis-Whipple said. “That is because of the hard work done by our staff.” She said the high school’s Career and Technology Education program provides a wide range of vocational programs for students. The CTE program offers instruction in health, automotive technology, construction, cosmetology, culinary arts, drafting and design, early childhood education, graphic communication, information technology, and metal fabrication. “We have a phenomenal CTE program as well as an evening high school, which is amazing,” Curtis-Whipple said. Evening High School Principal Michelle Prendergast said Curtis-Whipple was very supportive of the academic program, including students of all ages. "She told me the evening school graduation ceremony was one of her favorite calendar events of the year," she said. "She has always said, if there was anything I needed, I could reach out to her. I always felt she had confidence in me to do the job, and that is always nice to have. I wish her well in her future endeavors." Curtis-Whipple said the schools have also been enhanced by students taking part in athletics, drama, and music programs. "When I was in high school, the drama program was under the direction of Jan Smith," she said. "She was amazing, and she got me to come out of my shell a little bit." Smith served as director of the Weymouth High Theater Company for 30 years until she retired in June 2011. Some of Smith’s well-known students included Actor Nate Corddry, a 1995 Weymouth High graduate, and his classmate Donnie Norton, director of the high school theater company. "It is telling when you see how far people further themselves professionally," Curtis-Whipple said. “One thing I do love is how so many people come back to support students grow into their potential and give back to the school system.” ![The demol --- Result 5 --- Title: Stars School & Learning Center in Weymouth Sets Opening Date for September 2025 Link: https://www.accessnewswire.com/newsroom/en/education/stars-school-and-learning-center-in-weymouth-sets-opening-date-for-september-2025-1030340 Snippet: Developed and led by South Shore Stars CEO Jennifer Curtis-Whipple, Ed.D., a former Superintendent of Weymouth Public Schools, the school is a natural extension of Stars' five-decade commitment to early education, academic enrichment, and family ... Content: (HTTP 403)

# A New Chapter Begins!

The Stars School & Learning Center officially opened its doors on **September 4th**, welcoming our very first students into a school designed to support bright learners who experience challenges such as **dyslexia and other language-based learning needs**.

On September 25th, we gathered with **Mayor Mike Molisse**, our dedicated teachers, Stars Board Members, community supporters, and supportive parents to celebrate this milestone with a **Ribbon Cutting Ceremony.**

This vision would not have been possible without the extraordinary leadership of **Dr. Jennifer Curtis, CEO of South Shore Stars**, and the tireless work of **Anastasia Frank, our new School Director**, who guided the School through the rigorous **Massachusetts DESE 766 approval process** — the designation required for specialized private schools serving students with learning differences.

The Stars School & Learning Center is now officially open, a place where students with dyslexia and related learning challenges can thrive, discover their strengths, and unlock their full potential.

We are grateful to our community, families, and partners for believing in this vision and making it a reality. The journey has just begun!

# South Shore Stars School & Learning Center
## Comprehensive Information Report
**Report Date:** February 13, 2026  
**Website:** https://southshorestars.org  
**Focus:** Elementary-Age Students (Grades 1-8) with Learning Disabilities

---

## Executive Summary

Stars School & Learning Center is a private nonprofit day school in Weymouth, Massachusetts, serving students in grades K-8 (now approved for K-8 as of January 2026, initially opened for grades 1-6) with dyslexia and other language-based learning differences. The school officially opened on September 4, 2025, making it the first school of its kind on Boston's South Shore.

**Location:** 163 Libbey Parkway, Weymouth, MA  
**Opened:** September 4, 2025  
**Parent Organization:** South Shore Stars, Inc. (serving families since 1970)

---

## 1. PROGRAM DESCRIPTIONS & CURRICULUM

### Educational Philosophy
> "When a bright child struggles in school, it is often a sign they need a different approach. Many students with dyslexia and other language-based learning differences are capable, curious, and smart; they simply learn differently."
> 
> Source: https://southshorestars.org/stars-school-learning-center/

The school operates on the principle that when teaching does not match how a student's brain works, school can become frustrating and confidence often takes a hit.

### Core Educational Approach

The Stars School & Learning Center offers:

- **Structured, supportive environment** with small class sizes
- **Evidence-based instruction** rooted in scientific research and best practices
- **Individualized support** based on diagnostic information
- **Multisensory, sequential, and systematic instructional approach**

### Teaching Methodology

#### Orton-Gillingham Approach
**Primary instructional method:** Expert instruction from Orton-Gillingham certified teachers, using state-of-the-art materials and proven methods to address specific learning differences.

> "Our staff will have the training to personalize instruction based upon the learner's needs. The ratio will be extremely low; at times, one staff member to three students."
> 
> Source: Boston Globe interview with Jennifer Curtis, January 31, 2025

## 2. ADMISSIONS REQUIREMENTS & PROCESS

### Admissions Philosophy

> "We believe the admissions process begins with a conversation."
> 
> Source: https://southshorestars.org/stars-school-learning-center/

### Admissions Process Steps

1. **Initial Inquiry:** Submit an inquiry to learn more about the program
2. **Family Call:** Admissions team schedules a call with the family to:
   - Discuss the child's learning profile
   - Answer questions
   - Share next steps
3. **Application:** If appropriate, families are invited to complete an application
4. **Required Forms:** Families are provided with any required forms as part of the application process

### School Information Packet

Families are encouraged to review the School Information Packet, which provides:
- Deeper overview of the program
- Educational approach details
- Admissions process information

This resource is designed to help families learn more prior to or during the inquiry stage.

### Rolling Admissions

> "The Stars School & Learning Center offers rolling admissions, allowing families to apply throughout the year as space becomes available. This flexible enrollment model ensures that students can access specialized support when it is most needed, rather than waiting for traditional enrollment cycles."
> 
> Source: https://southshorestars.org/dese-approval-for-grades-k-8-at-stars-school-learning-center/

The school is able to accommodate mid-year transfer students.

### Student Profile - Good Fit

The school may be a good fit if your child:
- Is bright but struggles with reading, writing, or language
- Has dyslexia or a language-based learning difference
- Has ADHD as a co-occurring challenge
- Needs structured, multi-sensory instruction
- Is not thriving in a traditional classroom

### Student Profile - Not a Good Fit

This may not be the right fit if:
- Your child does not have language-based learning needs
- You are looking for a general enrichment program
- Your child is best served in a large, traditional classroom

### Documentation Requirements

> "Some families might have a full battery of assessments, but some families do not. Some families are coming to us with the data from the dyslexia screeners from their school departments, or they're coming with curriculum-based assessments that their school department is doing. We're looking at that information and then taking anecdotal data to see if we're a good fit for their child. Is a neuropsychological test good practice? Yes. But do you have to have that? No. Our team is skilled, so a lot of them can do advanced testing if needed."
> 
> Source: Boston Globe interview with Jennifer Curtis, January 31, 2025

### Target Population

> "Students with language-based learning differences, like dyslexia and co-occurring conditions, including ADHD. This first-of-its-kind on Boston's South Shore day school will offer a unique experience for students with average to above-average intelligence, whose diverse learning styles may not be leveraged by a traditional academic setting."
> 
> Source: Beyond Kids Reading Directory, September 24, 2024
> https://www.beyondkidsreading.org/south-shore-stars-school-learning-center/

### Tuition Cost

(Day student tuition at Landmark, a well-regarded 766 North Shore school focusing on dyslexia for kids in 2nd through 12th grades, is $75,500.)"
> 
> Source: Boston Globe interview with Dr. Jennifer Curtis-Whipple, January 31, 2025

### Chapter 766 Approval & Public Funding

**Full Chapter 766 Approval Status:** Achieved November 2025

> "We are thrilled to announce that Stars School & Learning Center has officially received FULL Approval as a Chapter 766 School! This milestone allows us to partner directly with public school systems and provide students with the individualized, high-quality educational support they deserve with access to public funding as one way to make it possible."
> 
> Source: November 24, 2025 announcement
> https://southshorestars.org/stars-school-learning-center-receives-full-chapter-766-approval-expanding-access-to-publicly-funded-educational-support/

**DESE K-8 Approval:** Achieved January 2026

> "South Shore Stars is proud to announce that the Stars School & Learning Center has received approval from the Massachusetts Department of Elementary and Secondary Education (DESE) to serve students in grades K–8 with dyslexia and language-based learning differences."
> 
> Source: January 28, 2026 announcement
> https://southshorestars.org/dese-approval-for-grades-k-8-at-stars-school-learning-center/

### Funding Options

#### 1. Private Pay
Students can be directly enrolled by families paying tuition.

#### 2. Public School District Placement (Chapter 766)
> "As a nonprofit, Chapter 766-approved day school, Stars accepts both private-pay students and those placed by public school districts. Recently approved tuition rates by the Massachusetts Operational Services Division will allow public districts to access state and municipal funding for appropriate student placements."
> 
> Source: South Shore Times, June 4, 2025

#### 3. Circuit-Breaker Funding
> "These schools offer specialized private instruction and can work with school districts to access a portion of tuition through the circuit-breaker program, a state-funded reimbursement process. This means that, in some cases, qualifying students could receive out-of-district placements from their home district with a portion of costs covered."
> 
> Source: Boston Globe, January 31, 2025

### How Chapter 766 Works

**What is Chapter 766?**
> "Chapter 766 is the Massachusetts law that guarantees the rights of all young people with special needs (age 3-22) to an educational program best suited to their needs. Team evaluations and Annual Reviews are conducted to develop an ongoing individual education plan that ensures an appropriate education."
> 
> Source: Dyslexia Now What review, August 15, 2023
> https://www.dyslexianowwhat.com/actions/kgka1dwdz61rakdp00mducrhaipdzm

**How Funding Works:**
- If a family is going through the IEP process and their team decides that the district does not have the services within its own programming
- The team decides it's a better placement for a child
- They work with the 766 school to develop a contract
- The district sends the child directly, with costs partially covered by state and municipal funding
- Sometimes families may need to hire advocates or attorneys if the process becomes contentious

### Scholarship Fund

> "A scholarship fund is being established, and leadership is now refocusing its fundraising efforts toward ensuring future financial flexibility and a sustainable future for the school and the organization."
> 
> Source: South Shore Times, June 4, 2025

> 
> Source: Boston Globe, January 31, 2025

#### Professional Collaboration
The school emphasizes "professional collaboration with South Shore Stars Educational Staff" and ongoing professional development.

### Teaching Methodologies

#### 1. Orton-Gillingham Approach
Primary evidence-based methodology for students with dyslexia. This approach is:
- **Systematic:** Follows a logical, sequential order
- **Multi-sensory:** Engages multiple learning pathways
- **Sequential:** Builds skills progressively
- **Explicit:** Direct, clear instruction
- **Structured:** Organized and comprehensive

#### 2. Science of Reading
> "Rich is widely recognized for his expertise in literacy. Throughout his career, he worked to strengthen principals' and district leaders' understanding of the Science of Reading and championed the use of research-based, developmentally appropriate instruction."

The Science of Reading represents a comprehensive body of research about how children learn to read, emphasizing:
- Phonemic awareness
- Phonics
- Fluency
- Vocabulary
- Comprehension

#### 3. Personalized Learning Plans
Each student receives instruction tailored to their diagnostic information and individual learning profile.

#### 4. Co-Teaching Model
The school uses a co-teaching approach, particularly integrating the speech and language pathologist throughout the day rather than as isolated pull-out sessions.

> "Some families might have a full battery of assessments, but some families do not. We're looking at that information and then taking anecdotal data to see if we're a good fit for their child. Is a neuropsychological test good practice? Yes. But do you have to have that? > "Stars School & Learning Center believes neurodiversity is a strength. ### Fundraising Campaign

**Building the Gift of Literacy**

> "Together, we can give the gift that changes everything."

### Educational Vision

Expanding our approved grade levels allows us to provide continuity of support during the years when academic demands increase and confidence matters most."

**Dr. Jennifer Curtis-Whipple, Founding CEO:**
> "The community needs this program, and we have worked hard to get to a point where we are able to begin providing these services. All children deserve high-quality education, and we are ready to offer this specialized instruction for children with dyslexia."

> "I specifically enjoyed working with students that have difficulty learning and being able to support them, see them flourish and grow with the right teaching strategies."

**Richard Bransfield, School Director:**
> "His commitment to ensuring that every child learns to read with confidence has shaped the work of educators across the district and continues to influence his leadership today."

### From the School's Philosophy

> "When a bright child struggles in school, it is often a sign they need a different approach. | **Small Group Ratio** | Can be as low as 3:1 for intensive instruction |

| **Admissions** | Rolling (year-round) |

---

## Core Program Elements

### Teaching Methodology
- **Orton-Gillingham certified teachers**
- **Science of Reading** approach
- **Multisensory, systematic, sequential instruction**
- **Personalized learning plans**

### What Students Receive
✓ Individualized diagnostic-based learning plans  
✓ Orton-Gillingham instruction  
✓ Small class sizes  
✓ Individual academic support  
✓ Speech-language therapy (integrated, not pull-out)  
✓ Sensory and motor support  
✓ Executive functioning support  
✓ Specials (music, gym)  

---

## Leadership

- **Dr. Renée Heywood** - CEO, South Shore Stars
- **Richard Bransfield** - School Director (40+ years K-12 education, former Executive Director of Elementary Education for Weymouth Public Schools)
- **Dr. Jennifer Curtis-Whipple, Ed.D.** - Founding CEO (former Weymouth Superintendent)

---

## Admissions Process

1. Submit inquiry at website
2. Schedule call with admissions team
3. Review School Information Packet
4. Submit application (if good fit)
5. Complete required forms

**No fixed deadline - rolling admissions year-round**

---

## Funding Options

### Private Pay
$67,000 annual tuition

### Public School District Placement (Chapter 766)
- Work with child's IEP team
- District requests out-of-district placement
- Costs partially covered by state/municipal funding
- Circuit-breaker reimbursement available

### Scholarships
Scholarship fund in development

---

## Good Fit If Your Child:

✓ Is bright but struggles with reading, writing, or language  
✓ Has dyslexia or language-based learning difference  
✓ Has ADHD as co-occurring challenge  
✓ Needs structured, multi-sensory instruction  
✓ Is not thriving in traditional classroom  

## Not a Good Fit If:

✗ Child does not have language-based learning needs  
✗ Looking for general enrichment program  
✗ Child best served in large, traditional classroom  

---

## Therapy Services

### Integrated Throughout Day
- Full-time Speech-Language Pathologist (co-teaching model)
- Occupational therapy support
- Executive functioning development
- Sensory integration
- Gross motor activities

### State-of-the-Art Facility
$1.4 million renovation including:
- Specialized classrooms
- Gross motor and sensory space
- Self-regulation tools
- Specialized equipment

163 Libbey Parkway  
Weymouth, MA 02189

- Much smaller class sizes (8:1:1 vs 20+:1)
